questions.question: The 2020 presidential election will take place on Tuesday, Nov. 3, 2020.

imageMetadata.altText: Republican President Donald Trump & Democratic nominee Joe Biden in their 1st presidential debate.
imageMetadata.resources:
President Donald Trump and Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden participate in their first 2020 presidential campaign debate in Cleveland, Ohio, on September 29, 2020. REUTERS/Brian Snyder

For more lessons from PBS NewsHour EXTRA on election 2020, check out our "Super Civics 2020" series https://www.pbs.org/newshour/extra/tag/super-civics-2020/

questions.question: Out of 200 million registered voters in America in 2016, how many voted in the presidential election?

imageMetadata.altText: Alexis Rodriguez, 19, of Phoenix, Arizona, speaks to Reuters about being a young voter.
imageMetadata.resources:
Alexis Rodriguez, 19, who lives in Maricopa County, speaks to Reuters at Promise Arizona's offices in the Maricopa County city of Phoenix, Arizona, on May 23, 2019. Rodriguez was too young to participate in Trump's first election. Now 19, he came of age politically as Trump's conservative presidency seemed to take aim at his identities as young, gay and Latino. "It scares me to this day, just knowing that I may be under attack," he said.  REUTERS/Brian Snyder

PBS lesson "Will young voters turn out to vote this year?" https://www.pbs.org/newshour/extra/daily-videos/will-young-voters-turn-out-to-vote-this-year/

questions.question: How many of you will be able to vote in the 2020 presidential election?

choices.answer: I will be old enough and plan to vote.
I will be old enough but do not plan to vote.
I will not be old enough but am excited to vote one day.
I will not be old enough and have not thought a lot about voting.

imageMetadata.resources:
Stickers saying "I Voted Today" are given out to voters in the Democratic primary in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, June 2, 2020. REUTERS/Rachel Wisniewski

questions.question: President Donald Trump and former VP Joe Biden are the major party candidates. Do you know any third party candidates?

choices.answer: There are no third party candidates running this election cycle.
Hmm, what are third party candidates?

imageMetadata.altText: Photo of Democratic nominee Joe Biden wearing a mask and President Donald Trump not wearing a mask.
imageMetadata.resources:
Roughly half of Americans -- 53 percent -- said they would vote for former Vice President Joe Biden over President Donald Trump if the 2020 election were held today in the last PBS NewsHour/NPR/Marist poll in August 2020. Photos by Joshua Roberts and Carlos Barria/Reuters

Additional resource: PBS Lesson: "What students can take away from the first presidential debate" https://www.pbs.org/newshour/extra/daily-videos/what-students-can-take-away-from-the-first-presidential-debate/

questions.title: Learn about the role of local elections!
questions.description: The 2020 election is not just about the presidential candidates! Local and state candidates, as well as ballot initiatives, play a role further down on the ballot. Ballot initiatives let people vote directly on the issues.
questions.resources: PBS Lesson plan: "Down-ballot voting and the role of local elections" via PBS NewsHour EXTRA https://www.pbs.org/newshour/extra/lessons-plans/down-ballot-voting-lesson-plan/ with video produced by We the Voters.

questions.question: How many female vice presidential candidates have there been before Sen. Kamala Harris?

imageMetadata.altText: Democrat vice presidential nominee Sen. Kamala Harris and Republican Vice President Mike Pence
imageMetadata.resources: Additional resource: PBS Lesson: "Joe Biden chooses Kamala Harris as running mate" lesson via PBS NewsHour EXTRA https://www.pbs.org/newshour/extra/daily-videos/joe-biden-chooses-kamala-harris-as-running-mate/ Sen. Harris is also the first Black and Asian woman nominee from a major party.

Harris is also the first Black and Asian woman nominee from a major party.

questions.question: Election issues: Which of the following statements comes closest to your view?

choices.answer: The government should do a little more to help needy Americans.
The government should do a lot more to help needy Americans.
I'm not sure what government does when it comes to helping needy Americans.
The government should not be involved in helping needy Americans.
